subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today, I'm
going to respond to a request from a
viewer that I talk about psychedelics.
First of all, let me say that I've always
been open about the fact that I've used
psychedelics and it's been an important
part of my exploration going back to the
late 1960s when I was an undergraduate
college student. You know, I recently read
an account of shamans who engage in the
use of psychoactive drug rituals in a
shamanistic context. An
anthropologist once asked a shaman why
do you use these drugs? He said to
the anthropologist, "To keep the mind from
crystallizing." In other words, from
hardening, from getting arteriosclerosis
of the mind, hardening of the
attitudes, so to speak. You have to
appreciate the cultural context of this
because as a child growing up in the
1950s, it was what you could call a
Norman Rockwell universe. Everything
seemed good and complete. There was
no reason not to trust the authorities.
The United States had emerged victorious
from the Second World War. The economy
was booming. I grew up in a small town in
Wisconsin. My father owned a furniture
store and it was natural for me to
figure that I would go into the
furniture business when I completed
college. I started my career as an
undergraduate student in Madison with
a business major. I completed my career
four years later writing a senior honors
thesis on the psychology of religious
mysticism. So, that was a transition.
Of course, the Vietnam War era caused the
whole generation of college students in
particular to question authority. We used
to say, "Don't trust anybody over 30," back
then. It was as if all of the ground
rules that had been laid out for us
were being called into question. I
think there's no doubt in my mind that
psychedelic drugs had a big part in
opening me up to considering things
differently. Believe it or not, I actually
had conservative attitudes when I
entered college. I didn't vote until 1968.
And so, I had never voted anything but
Democratic throughout my entire life. But,
when I entered college as a freshman, I
had fallen under the influence of one of
my high school teachers who was a
conservative economist. I had very
distinct conservative attitudes, and
those all changed within a couple of
years. I want to say something about
the set and setting. I can tell you this.
I've used psychedelic drugs over a
hundred times. That's simply
a fact. That includes a wide variety:
LSD, psilocybin, mescaline, peyote,
ayahuasca, mushrooms, cactus...
I have... MDMA, also known as ecstasy. I've
sampled all of those, although it's been
a very long time since I've had any
psychedelics at all. Nevertheless, I was
quite influenced by naturally, in that
era, Timothy Leary, Richard Alpert, Ralph
Metzner, the pioneers of the psychedelic
revolution, their book, The Psychedelic
Experience, based on the Tibetan Book of
the Dead. But my own experiences while
using LSD also prompted me to question
reality. I know there was one occasion in
which I heard a voice. I heard a friend
of mine talking to me, a person who was
several blocks away. When I asked her,
"Were you sending me a telepathic message?"
She said, "No." So I came to understand that
under psychedelics you can have the
illusion of being psychic. Now, there's
some research that shows that
psychedelics enhance parapsychological
scores and tests, but basically the
findings are relatively weak and
inconsistent. So, I don't think in terms
of taking tests for ESP that
psychedelics is a good idea. That doesn't
mean that they don't facilitate psychic
functioning. But who wants to take a test
under those circumstances? Perhaps
some people do. But set and setting is
very important. I think one of the
reasons why, in my experience of a lot of
psychedelic drug use in my early years,
with never a bad experience, well maybe
once a mildly bad experience... I remember
I lived in a farmhouse outside of
Madison, Wisconsin and I took a walk and
next door was the wastewater treatment
plant, the sewage plant, and it kind of
smelled of sulfur fumes. Walking
around outdoors at night near the waste
disposal plant, I had the feeling of , "Oh,
there's something hellish going on."
Of course the flames and the fumes, it
did have kind of a hellish atmosphere.
But that was the worst of it. It was
very mild and very brief. But why have
my experiences always been positive
when other people haven't had positive
experiences consistently? In fact,
some people, as we know, have committed
suicide or done other foolish things
while using drugs. Well, set and setting. I
was always a student - in psychology. I
took drugs
with friends, we engaged in intellectual
discussions, and I've taken psychedelics with
some of my colleagues and mentors and
probably a few people who have been
interviewed on this program. The
point being, the set and the setting was
always positive. Frankly, I'm a person
with a pretty stable emotional and
psychological background. For example,
I'm about to celebrate my 40th wedding
anniversary, so I'm not prone to go
off the deep end, unlike many other
people I know. It just happens to be an
accident of birth or karma. But those
factors, the supportive setting, and the
fact that I'm basically a very stable
person psychologically enabled me to
engage in these experiences over and
over again without really any detriment
to myself at all. I can tell you this.
When I was a student in criminology at
Berkeley, I spent a lot of time studying
drug rehabilitation programs and
studying the legal status of psychedelic
drugs and interacting with a number of
professors there, both pro and cons with
regard to drug use. One of those
professors was Hardin Jones, professor
of, as I recall, medical physics. He
was definitely a right-wing Republican
anti-drug guy. Here I was, this
long-haired hippie, using a lot of drugs.
He gave a lecture I attended on one
occasion in which he said, "People who use
drugs, it affects their intellectual
functioning." So after class I went up to
him and I said, "Doctor Jones, I have a
straight-A average." In fact, I think at
the time I had the highest
scores of any student in the school of
criminology.
He was surprised. He looked at me
and he said, "Gee, I'd like to talk to you."
So I met with him many times in his
office privately just to talk to him
about my drug use. He had to admit,
you know, as he got to know me, that I
didn't seem to be suffering from any
intellectual deficits. Although he always
said, "Maybe you would have been
even brighter." I think the opposite. I
think that there is a sense in which the
use of psychedelic drugs for me opened
me up, expanded my mind, increased my
curiosity. I've been an explorer of
consciousness, dedicated to using drugs
for the very purpose of self-exploration,
to use the psychedelic drugs as a
sort of a microscope into my own
consciousness. That's always been my
focus. I saw a movie
recently, a very good movie. I think
it was called The Rider, in which as a
young American Indian boy, he's
had a brain injury and he's with his
friends and they say to him, "Let's go get
f*****." Well, what that was all about was
going out into nature and lighting a
campfire and ringing the guitar and
singing and opening up and talking and
sure they were probably drinking
something or smoking something, but that
was never the way I used those drugs.
It's not that I didn't party, I did. But
the parties always had a focus,
a focus of deep inquiry about them. And
that's the context in which I think I
was able to get the most out of that
drug use. I'm well aware of the fact
that not all people have had such
positive experiences and I'm also well
aware of the fact that I've avoided
certain drugs. I've never really gotten
into heroin or cocaine or methedrine.
Although, I can tell you this, when I was
an undergraduate at Madison, if I had to
study all night to take an exam the next
day, which I seemed to do on a regular
basis, I'd go to the student infirmary
and ask for some dexedrine and they'd
just hand it out to me back in those
days. Dexedrine is an amphetamine,
relatively mild, but strong enough to
keep you up all night studying. And so I'd
study all night, take the test in the
morning, do well typically, and then crash.
So that's my experience, and I'm
proud of it. I think it's a shame
that we're not researching these
substances - entheogens, they're now
called - more. I can say, along the way, I've
interviewed many people about drugs. In
fact, I'm going to link
to it, right now. There are, I think, only 7
videos in the New Thinking Allowed series
at the moment. It's a playlist called
"Entheogens
in Consciousness." If you do some
Google searches for the original
Thinking Allowed series, you'll find that
I've interviewed Ram Dass. I've
interviewed Houston Smith, who is a deep
explorer of psychedelic drugs and
a first rate philosopher as well. I've done
several interviews with Terence McKenna
on drugs. Robert Anton Wilson was a
friend of mine, I've interviewed him
about drugs. So, my attitude is that drugs
have had, overall, a very positive
influence in our society. Now, I'm
referring to psychedelics and marijuana,
not to all drugs. But I think it's
probably fair to say that the
psychedelics have had a much more
positive influence over all on our
society than alcohol or tobacco.
They're probably safer than alcohol and
tobacco, as well. Well, what's in all of
this discussion for you? I would say this.
You might begin to ask yourself, if
you've used psychedelics, how was it for
you? Did you use them in the best way
possible
or did you misuse them? It's something to
think about. Were you harmed by them? If
you were harmed by them, what have you
done? Have you been through any sort of
recovery program, any sort of therapy? Are
you comfortable talking about this? Did
they open you up in important ways? I
know one thing that I experienced early
on, and many other people report it, when
you take LSD and look at another person,
you can see their face change over and
over and over again, you'll see different
faces as you look at that person. It's as
if you're looking at a whole string of
past lives. It was one of the things
truly that opened me up to wanting to
study parapsychology, to realizing the
importance of this discipline. Even when
the drugs involved hallucinations - as I
say, I had an auditory hallucination that
I mistook for telepathy on one occasion -
it made me question deeply the
functioning of my mind.
Do you question the functioning of your
mind? Are there areas in which the crust
of social conditioning needs to be blown
away in your case? I'll leave you with that
thought. And once again, thank you for being
with me.
